On Wednesday 21 September 2005 13:11, Elliotte Harold wrote:
> Robert Watkins wrote:
> > Certain output streams automatically convert \n to the line seperator
> > of the platform you are on.
>
> Really? Which ones? That's certainly not standard behavior, and it's not
> true of System.out, which is the stream at issue here.

It's always puzzled me why Java got this wrong (yes, I think "wrong"
is the appropriate term) when even C got it right. It means, for
example, that various strings cannot be constants.

> In general code should not be written to depend on the system line
> separator. That worked well when programs and data spent their entire
> lives on one computer, or perhaps a few computers all running the same
> OS. In the world of the Internet and Java, that's no longer true.
> Programs should explicitly specify the line separator character(s) they
> write or read. Their output should not vary from one platform to the next.

Well, that's an interesting choice. I might even make it, under enough
pressure.

Wouldn't it be good enough to provide a wrapper class for one's
output streams, which did the translation (or not) as required?

-- 
Chris "as graphite to diamond" Dollin
The software engineer's song: "who knows where the time goes".
